alt_statements.statement: As a progressive educator and administrator, I believe university leaders must protect students’ rights to peacefully protest on Israel/Gaza while drawing a firm line against harassment, intimidation, or discrimination of any kind. Administrators should create structured, well-facilitated forums for dialogue—much like we do in K–12 around difficult topics—grounded in clear conduct policies, trauma-informed support, and an emphasis on shared human dignity.

As someone who believes deeply in both free expression and human dignity, I think university administrators should protect peaceful protest on Israel/Gaza—including sharp, uncomfortable criticism—while drawing a firm line against harassment, doxxing, and threats toward any group of students. They should create structured forums and teach-ins where students can argue, grieve, and organize with facts and context, not just slogans, and apply clear, content-neutral rules consistently. Administrators ought to be transparent about their decisions, resist political pressure from donors or politicians, and focus on keeping campuses safe enough that Jewish, Muslim, Arab, and all other students feel they can both speak and simply exist without fear.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime trying to protect both people and places, I think campus administrators need to safeguard students’ right to protest while setting firm, even‑handed rules that keep everyone physically safe and free from harassment. They should create designated spaces for demonstrations, refuse to tolerate dehumanizing or threatening behavior from any side, and actively foster forums where students can study the history, law, and human cost of the Israel/Gaza conflict in depth.

University administrators need to protect free speech and peaceful protest, even when the topic is controversial, but they also have a responsibility to keep campuses safe and make sure nobody’s rights are trampled. They should set clear, consistent rules that apply to everyone—no harassment, no blocking buildings or classes, no vandalism—then enforce those rules firmly and fairly without playing politics.

As someone who values free expression and leans liberal, I think university administrators need to protect students’ rights to protest and speak out on Israel/Gaza, even when the message is uncomfortable, while drawing a clear, bright line at harassment, threats, or incitement to violence. They should apply rules consistently to all groups, avoid heavy-handed crackdowns, and instead create structured forums for dialogue where people can actually listen to each other rather than just shout past one another.

As someone who values education and community, I think university administrators should protect students’ rights to protest and speak out on Israel and Gaza, while drawing a firm line against harassment, hate speech, and violence toward any group. They should create structured spaces for dialogue—panels, teach-ins, and moderated discussions—so students can learn the history and complexity of the conflict, not just shout past each other.

I think university administrators should protect students’ rights to protest about Israel and Gaza, as long as demonstrations stay nonviolent and don’t turn into harassment or hate. Schools should create spaces for dialogue where Palestinian, Israeli, Jewish, Muslim, and all other students feel safe to share their experiences, and they should step in only when safety or human dignity is at risk.

University administrators should allow peaceful demonstrations about Israel and Gaza, but they must enforce clear rules so that protests don’t disrupt classes, threaten safety, or turn into harassment of any group. Free speech is important, but so is maintaining order, protecting all students, and keeping the focus on education—if a protest crosses the line into intimidation, vandalism, or blocking campus operations, it should be shut down quickly and consequences should follow.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime trying to listen carefully and create space for people to feel safe and heard, I think university administrators should fiercely protect peaceful protest while drawing a firm line against harassment, threats, and dehumanizing language toward any group. Students should be allowed—even encouraged—to grapple publicly with the hard realities of Israel and Gaza, but administrators must ensure clear, consistent rules that apply equally to everyone, and provide facilitated dialogue and education so this doesn’t devolve into intimidation or silencing.

University administrators need to protect free speech and peaceful protest, even when the Israel/Gaza demonstrations are emotionally charged and deeply polarizing, but they also have a clear duty to intervene when rhetoric crosses into harassment, threats, or discriminatory behavior. As someone who values both human rights and civil discourse, I’d like to see universities create structured, moderated forums and teach-ins where students can grapple with the history and human cost on all sides, rather than just reacting to slogans and social media. At the same time, administrators must be transparent and even-handed in enforcing rules, making it clear that safety, academic freedom, and basic dignity for Jewish, Muslim, Arab, and all other students are non-negotiable.

As someone who values both social justice and evidence-based decision-making, I think university administrators should protect students’ rights to peaceful protest while drawing a firm line at harassment, intimidation, or any form of violence. As a Jewish, progressive small business owner who came to this country as an immigrant, I believe university administrators must protect both free speech and the physical safety of all students, including Jewish and Muslim students, without demonizing either side. They should allow peaceful protests, set clear rules against harassment and threats, and create spaces for real dialogue and education about Israel and Gaza, rather than rushing to shut things down or take purely symbolic positions.

As someone who values both justice and open dialogue, I think university administrators should protect students’ rights to protest and express solidarity with Palestinians and Israelis alike, while drawing a firm line against harassment, doxxing, or threats of violence. I think university administrators should let students protest peacefully about Israel and Gaza, because people deserve the chance to speak up about what they believe is fair and just. Campus administrators should protect the broadest possible space for peaceful expression on all sides while drawing a bright, non-negotiable line at threats, harassment, and any attempt to shut others down. I think university administrators need to keep order first and foremost: students have a right to speak their minds, but not to bully, harass, or shut down other people’s education. As someone who teaches young people and cares deeply about social justice, I think university administrators should protect the right to protest and organize while setting clear, consistent boundaries that keep everyone physically safe and free from harassment or hate.
